title: 111_hr2324
content: The "Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2009" requires background checks at gun shows. The Congress finds that approximately 5,200 traditional gun shows are held annually in the US, attracting thousands of attendees and providing a convenient location for criminals to obtain firearms without background checks or records for tracing. Gun shows provide a centralized location for criminals to obtain firearms without background checks or tracing records. The term "gun show" is defined as an event where 50 or more firearms are offered for sale, exchange, or transfer. The term "gun show" refers to an event where 50 or more firearms are offered for sale, exchange, or transfer, with exceptions for sales from personal collections at private residences and events where individuals are not required to be licensed. The term "gun show" excludes sales, exchanges, or transfers by individuals from their personal collection at their private residence, as long as they are not required to be licensed. It also excludes events with less than 100 firearms offered for sale by private, not-for-profit organizations primarily focused on hunting activities. Gun show vendors are individuals who participate in gun shows where up to 100 firearms are offered for sale by private, not-for-profit organizations focused on hunting activities, attended only by members and their immediate families. Gun show vendors are individuals who exhibit, sell, offer for sale, transfer, or exchange firearms at gun shows, regardless of licensing status, and whether or not they have a fixed location at the show. Gun show vendors who are not licensed under section 923 and exhibit, sell, offer for sale, transfer, or exchange firearms at gun shows, regardless of arrangements with the show operator. Chapter 44 of the title is amended to include regulation of firearms transfers at gun shows, including the registration requirement for gun show operators over 21 years of age. Regulation of firearms transfers at gun shows includes a registration requirement for gun show operators over 21 years of age. The individual must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited from transporting firearms across state lines, and must not have violated any firearm regulations. To transport firearms or ammunition in interstate or foreign commerce, a person must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited by law, have not violated any firearm regulations, and register as a gun show operator with the Attorney General. To transport firearms or ammunition in interstate or foreign commerce, a person must be at least 21 years old, not prohibited by law, and register as a gun show operator with the Attorney General, providing fingerprints, a photograph, and certification of meeting specific requirements. To operate a gun show, a person must meet specific requirements, disclose all material information truthfully, and pay a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. To operate a gun show, a person must notify the Attorney General in writing of the event details and vendors, and pay a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. To operate a gun show, a person must notify the Attorney General in writing of the event details, verify vendors' identities, and pay a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. Before a gun show begins, the organizer must verify the identity of each vendor by checking a valid ID with a photo and have them sign a ledger with identifying information. Before a gun show begins, the organizer must verify the identity of each vendor by checking a valid ID with a photo and have them sign a ledger with identifying information, as well as a notice outlining the vendor's obligations under this chapter. Each attendee must also be notified of these requirements. The gun show organizer must verify vendors' identity with a valid photo ID and have them sign a ledger with identifying information and notice of obligations. Attendees must also be informed of these requirements. Vendors must maintain records demonstrating compliance with the regulations. The gun show organizer must notify attendees of the requirements of the chapter and maintain records to demonstrate compliance. Additionally, background checks are required before transferring firearms between unlicensed persons. The Attorney General requires compliance with regulations for record-keeping at gun shows. Unlicensed persons cannot transfer firearms without a background check. Unlicensed individuals at gun shows cannot transfer firearms without a background check and must comply with record-keeping regulations set by the Attorney General. Licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers must record firearm details and transaction information in a bound record, notify the parties about the background check system, and provide a unique identification number for the transfer. The licensee must provide a unique identification number to the prospective transferee to indicate that the transfer of the firearm would not violate federal or state laws. Recordkeeping requirements mandate that the licensee notify parties about the background check system and transfer details within 10 days. The licensee must submit a report to the Attorney General within 10 days of a firearm transfer, including details like make, model, and serial number, as required by regulations. The licensee must submit a report to the Attorney General within 10 days of a firearm transfer, specifying the make, model, and serial number of the firearm, as required by regulations. The report should not include identifying information of unlicensed persons involved in the transfer. The licensee must retain records of firearm transfers, including details required for inventory, in their permanent business records. Gun show vendors are not subject to additional recordkeeping requirements under this section. Penalties for non-compliance are outlined in Section 924(a) of the title. The licensee must keep records of firearm transfers in their permanent business records. Gun show vendors are exempt from additional recordkeeping requirements. Penalties for violations of Section 932 include fines and imprisonment. Whoever knowingly violates subsections of section 932 may face fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. Repeat offenders may face harsher penalties. The Attorney General may impose additional penalties on violators. The Attorney General may impose additional penalties on violators of section 932, including suspension or revocation of registration and a civil fine of up to $10,000. The Attorney General can suspend or revoke registration and impose a civil fine of up to $10,000 on violators of section 932. The Attorney General has the authority to inspect gun show operators' records and inventory during business hours for compliance with firearms transfer regulations. The Attorney General can inspect gun show operators' records and inventory without needing reasonable cause or a warrant to ensure compliance with firearms transfer regulations. The Attorney General can inspect gun show operators' records and inventory without needing reasonable cause or a warrant to ensure compliance with firearms transfer regulations. Amendments include reporting requirements for multiple sales at gun shows and increased penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees. Section 923(g)(3)(A) of the title is amended to include notice provision under section 932(c)(2) for selling or disposing of firearms. Section 924(a)(3) is amended to increase penalties for recordkeeping violations by licensed dealers, importers, manufacturers, or collectors who knowingly provide false information or violate section 922(m). Licensed dealers, importers, manufacturers, or collectors who knowingly make false statements or violate recordkeeping requirements may face fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both, under this title. Increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements include fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both, under this title. Increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements include fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both, under this title. The penalties for violations have been increased, with fines and imprisonment up to 10 years, or both, under section 922(t) of the title. Amendments to section 922(t) of title 18, United States Code include changes to subsections (s) and (t) and the elimination of certain elements of the offense. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives is authorized to hire additional personnel for inspecting gun shows. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives may hire 40 additional Industry Operations Investigators to inspect gun shows. Biennial reports on firearm sales at gun shows must be submitted to Congress. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives must report biennially to Congress on firearm sales at gun shows, including whether background checks are being conducted and any recommendations for improvement. Firearms are sold without background checks by the national instant criminal background check system established under the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act. Resources needed to enforce this section and recommendations for improvements to prevent such sales are discussed. Effective date for this section and its amendments is 180 days after enactment of the Act.
